brief_description: Reims, the 'Coronation City,' is a historic city in the Grand Est region that serves as the capital of Champagne and the traditional site where French kings were crowned. With its magnificent Notre-Dame de Reims Cathedral, world-famous champagne houses, and rich royal heritage, Reims offers visitors an authentic taste of French history, champagne culture, and the distinctive character of northern France.

sections.title: Champagne Heritage
sections.content: Reims' unique character is defined by its exceptional champagne heritage, home to some of the world's most prestigious champagne houses including Veuve Clicquot, Taittinger, and Pommery. The historic chalk cellars, vineyards, and champagne production methods create a distinctive urban identity that showcases the city's importance as the capital of Champagne and its continued cultural significance through the centuries.

sections.title: Royal Coronation History
sections.content: The city's rich history spans from Roman times through the Middle Ages to the modern era, preserved in landmarks like the historic cathedral, the Palais du Tau, and the ancient Porte de Mars. These structures tell the story of Reims' importance as the traditional coronation site of French kings and its role in French royal history.

sections.title: Gothic Architecture
sections.content: Reims is globally recognized for its magnificent Gothic cathedral, a UNESCO World Heritage site that represents the pinnacle of French medieval architecture. The city's cultural heritage continues to drive innovation, while Reims has evolved into a center for arts, festivals, and champagne tourism, balancing traditional heritage with contemporary urban development.

sections.title: Champagne Identity
sections.content: Reims embodies the warm hospitality and rich traditions of the Champagne region. Visitors experience this through traditional French cuisine featuring local specialties, champagne tastings, the lively atmosphere of local markets, and the genuine friendliness of residents who are proud to share their city's unique story as the heart of champagne production.

why_visit.intro: Reims offers visitors a unique opportunity to experience a French city that combines royal coronation heritage with world-famous champagne culture, featuring authentic local traditions, fascinating historical sites, and a distinctive northern character that's unlike anywhere else in France.

highlights.title: Notre-Dame de Reims Cathedral
highlights.content: Reims' magnificent Gothic cathedral creates a unique urban landscape that's become the city's signature feature. The ancient coronation site, stunning stained glass windows, and elegant Gothic architecture transform ordinary streets into striking historical statements, making every street corner a potential photo opportunity and creating a magical atmosphere throughout the city.

highlights.title: Place Drouet d'Erlon
highlights.content: The heart of Reims, this magnificent square is surrounded by important landmarks including the cathedral, elegant 19th-century architecture, and beautiful gardens. It's the perfect starting point for exploring the city and experiencing the daily life of Reims' residents.

highlights.title: Champagne House Tours
highlights.content: These world-famous champagne houses, located throughout the city, offer spectacular architecture and insights into Reims' champagne heritage with their stunning cellars and cultural significance. The tours represent the pinnacle of champagne tourism and continue to attract visitors from around the world.

highlights.title: Old Town Quarter
highlights.content: Reims' historic center offers authentic local experiences where visitors can explore narrow cobblestone streets, discover hidden squares, and admire the distinctive medieval and Renaissance architecture. The area is particularly atmospheric in the evening when the historic buildings take on a magical quality against the city backdrop.

highlights.title: Les Halles du Boulingrin
highlights.content: In the center of the city, the iconic covered market offers spectacular insights into Reims' culinary heritage and the surrounding Champagne landscape. Accessible by walking, it provides a unique perspective on the city's cultural importance and opportunities for culinary appreciation in a historic setting.

highlights.title: Champagne Heritage
highlights.content: The city's cultural heritage is celebrated through its champagne houses, markets, and traditional crafts, with the famous champagne production offering insights into the region's viticultural history and the famous Champagne appellation adding a unique dimension to the city's cultural landscape.

transport.public_transport: Reims has an efficient bus and tram system that serves the city and surrounding areas. Taxis are readily available and the city center is compact and walkable, making it easy to explore on foot.
transport.passes: Single tickets and day passes are available for public transport. The city center is easily navigable on foot, with most major attractions within walking distance.

spring.description: Spring brings pleasant temperatures and blooming flowers to Reims, making it an ideal time to explore the city on foot. The weather is comfortable for outdoor activities, and the surrounding Champagne countryside comes to life with seasonal colors and budding vines.

summer.description: Summer in Reims is warm and sunny, with the city's many parks and the nearby Champagne countryside providing pleasant retreats. Evening temperatures are comfortable, making it perfect for enjoying the city's vibrant café culture and outdoor dining scene.

autumn.description: Autumn offers mild temperatures and beautiful fall colors, particularly in the surrounding Champagne countryside. The weather is ideal for exploring the city and nearby natural attractions, with the added bonus of champagne harvest experiences and fewer crowds than the summer months.

winter.description: Winter in Reims is cold and occasionally snowy. The city takes on a cozy atmosphere, with indoor attractions like museums, champagne houses, and the historic center providing warm refuge. The nearby Champagne countryside offers winter landscape beauty.
